awd_titl_txt: Students Engaging In Science and Mathematics Interdisciplinary Collaborations - SEISMIC
awd_abstract_narration:
Students Engaging In Science and Mathematics Interdisciplinary Collaborations, or SEISMIC, is using learning communities to help low-income, academically talented students from Bridgewater State University (BSU) in Southeastern Massachusetts become confident STEM majors who experience science and mathematics as a collaborative, interdisciplinary field. SEISMIC is increasing the number of STEM graduates who possess the skills needed to address problems of modern society.  Research conducted by the SEISMIC grant team is helping to establish whether an interdisciplinary problem-based and service-learning curriculum promotes the success of academically talented, low-income STEM students.  Additionally, SEISMIC Scholars are enhancing scientific understanding and increasing public scientific literacy through service learning activities. 

SEISMIC Scholarships are helping BSU close achievement gaps in retention and graduation rates for low-income science and mathematics majors.  Students eligible for SEISMIC Scholarships are low-income students who earned a 3.0 GPA and B- or better in their introductory course in biology, chemistry, computer science, geology, mathematics or physics.  Scholars maintaining high GPAs receive awards of up to $6,000 for the final three years of their studies in BSU STEM fields. Through analysis of student work, student records data, and Likert and open-response surveys of Scholars and a control group consisting of eligible students who did not receive scholarships, the SEISMIC grant team is evaluating how participating in an interdisciplinary problem-based and service-learning curriculum leads to increases in STEM retention and motivation, as well as the development of the social, psychological and cultural capital that help graduates succeed in the workforce.

por.por_cntn:
Students Engaging In Scientific and Mathematical Interdisciplinary Collaborations (SEISMIC) was an NSF S-STEM grant funded between February 2017 and June 2023. The grant supported 53 low-income, academically talented science and mathematics undergraduate students with financial scholarships, curricular and co-curricular support. The overarching goal of SEISMIC was to graduate more low-income students with science and mathematics degrees while also training those students to approach science and mathematics through a broad, interdisciplinary lens.

Thirty-eight SEISMIC Scholars fully participated in the program, receiving financial, curricular and co-curricular support between their sophomore and senior years of college. Of the 38 students who received full support, 35 graduated with science and mathematics degrees. An additional fifteen students were supported financially for their final one to two years of studies in science and mathematics, and all fifteen of these students will graduate with STEM degrees.

These supported low-income students were retaining in science and mathematics at a higher rate than similar low-income students who did not receive support. Approximately 64% of low-income students who did not receive support graduated with a science or mathematics degree, compared to 92% of students receiving this scholarship and support. This suggests that the result of scholarship and programmatic support led to 11 additional science and mathematics undergraduate degrees within the 38 fully supported SEISMIC scholars.

Post-graduation, 76% of SEISMIC scholars are employed in a science or mathematics field or are pursuing advanced science or mathematics degrees. An additional 11% are seeking science or mathematics employment currently.

A significant impact from the scholarship and grant program was evident for students who entered the program as sophomores in the fall of 2020. The onset of the COVID 19 pandemic in spring 2020 substantially impacted higher education. Low-income students appear to have been significantly harmed. The final cohort of scholars were selected in spring 2020 as the pandemic closed campus. In this final cohort, 82% of scholars graduated with science and mathematics degrees, compared with only 38% of similar low-income students who did not receive scholarship support. We speculate that the possibility of significant financial support, the added advising, and the sense of belonging to a group gave the scholars a reason to return and stick with science and mathematics studies in a way that equally strong academically and equally at risk financially students who weren’t supported did not find. 

Scholarship recipients took advantage of opportunities to engage in research and lab training, added mentoring and advising, and a curriculum that fostered a deeper understanding of how science and mathematics intersect with society. Early research opportunities placed students from different majors in interdisciplinary teams to tackle real-world problems. Later, scholars took a philosophy course “Science, Values and Society” that examined how society’s interests and views of evidence impact how science is done. Students also took a special section of “Cultural Psychology” where students studied different cultural views of science and mathematics, and how the culture of science impacts who participates in science.

The results of the SEISMIC grant program, and explanations of the activities and opportunities presented to scholars, have been widely disseminated at national and regional meetings of Project Kaleidoscope in conjunction with the American Associate of Colleges and Universities, at disciplinary meetings in sociology, and in peer reviewed publications. Lessons learned from this project have informed scholarship programs at the host university and similar programs in the region.
